doc.title: G10 Consumer Dashboard: August 2025: Consumer Sentiment Improves Outside the Euro Area
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/G10 Consumer Dashboard_ August 2025_ Consumer Sentiment Improves Outside the Euro Area_2025-09-01

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: We update our G10 consumer dashboard through August. G10 consumers continue to benefit from tight labor markets and healthy balance sheets, but sentiment and spending are subdued.

Household balance sheet fundamentals generally remain strong. Household net worth as a share of income continues to rank at or above percentile 80 (P80) in the US, Japan, Australia, the Euro area and Canada, and close to P50 in the UK. That said, real net worth growth has been weak in most economies since the start of the year, standing around P40 in the Euro area, P30 in the UK and Canada, P20 in Australia and the US, and below P10 in Japan. The saving rate is below its pre- pandemic level in the US, close to its pre- pandemic average in Australia, but remains elevated elsewhere. That said, recent data show a decline in the saving rate in Canada (Exhibit 10).
Consumer sentiment remains below its historical average across the G10 (Exhibit 14). Since we last published the dashboard, sentiment improved in most economies but deteriorated in the Euro area.

In most DMs, falling headline inflation, tight labor markets, and slowing but still- elevated wage growth are still supporting real income, although growth is moderating. Since we last published the dashboard, real income growth ticked up in the US, Canada and Japan, moved sideways in the Euro area and Australia, but slowed in the UK. In the UK, private sector regular pay growth decelerated to \(4.8\%\) on a 3m MA yoy basis in June, and remains on track to notably undershoot the BoE's estimate of \(5.2\%\) for Q2. In Japan, nominal cash wage growth accelerated to \(2.5\%\) yoy, due to a boost from special wages (which include summer bonuses and account for over \(40\%\) of June wages).
Since we last published the dashboard, real spending growth ticked up in the US, the Euro area, Canada and Japan, and moved sideways in the UK and Australia.

Consumers generally continue to benefit from healthy labor markets outside of Canada and the UK. The unemployment rate is close to its historical low in the Euro area (6.2%), Japan (2.3%), and Australia (4.2%) and it stands around P70 in the US (4.2%), P30 in the UK (4.7% 3m MA), and P20 in Canada (6.9%). Since we last published the dashboard, the unemployment rate increased in the US, moved sideways in Canada, the UK and the Euro area, and declined in Australia and Japan. In the UK, the HMRC payrolls data was revised higher in June, and the July print was slightly firmer than expected. That said, we continue to expect
further labor market weakening.

Debt service ratios remain low by historical standards in the US, the Euro area, and Japan, ticked down in Canada, and are cresting in Australia and the UK (where most mortgages have short periods of fixed rates) following central bank rate cuts. House prices edged up outside the US (Exhibit 16). Outstanding mortgage debt growth slowed (but remains positive) in the US, Euro area, the UK and Japan, and moved sideways in Canada and Australia. Overall, mortgage credit growth remains subdued (Exhibit 17- Exhibit 19).

Based on our percentile- based metrics, the Euro area and Japan consumer health stands at or above P60, followed by the US and Australia around P40. Consumer health stands around P35 in Canada and P30 in the UK. Since we last published the dashboard, overall consumer health generally edged up slightly outside of the UK.
Exhibit 1: Fundamentals Remain a Source of Strength, but Spending Growth Has Fallen Below P50 in Most Economies

\\* Percentile is inverted. High percentiles correspond to positive outcomes (e.g., low unemployment). We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average. We have excluded pension assets from UK net worth in measuring the net-worth-to-income ratio as of June 2025, see methodological notes below for further details.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 2: Real Spending Growth Improved in the Euro Area and US; Real Income Growth Improved in Japan but Worsened in the UK
\\*Percentile is inverted, such that high percentiles correspond to positive outcomes.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 3: Our Consumer Health Indicator Stands Around P40 in the US and P35 in Canada
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 4: Our Consumer Health Indicator Stands Around P60 in the Euro Area and P35 in the UK
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 5: Our Consumer Health Indicator Stands Around P60 in Japan and P45 in Australia
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 6: Nominal Spending Growth Tickled Up in the US but Slowed in Canada on a 3m MA Basis
Source:Haver Analytics,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 7: Real Retail Sales Growth Tickled Up in the Euro Area and Improved but Remained Negative in the UK on a 3m MA Basis
Source:Haver Analytics,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 8: Nominal Spending Growth Declined in Japan but Accelerated in Australia on a 3m MA Basis
Source:Haver Analytics,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 9: Goods Spending Has Normalized to Pre-Pandemic Levels in the US, Australia, Italy, and Japan but Remains Depressed in Germany, France, UK, and Canada
Source:Haver Analytics,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 10: The Saving Rate Ticked Down in Canada and the UK but Remains Elevated, and Edged Up in Australia
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 11: Households Have Continued to Accumulate Excess Savings (As Typically Measured) Outside of the US
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 12: The Unemployment Rate Declined in Japan and Australia, Was Flat in the Euro Area, UK and Canada, and Ticked Up in the US
\\*The UK labor force survey has notably low participation rates.
Source: Haver Analytics, OECD, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 13: Wage Growth Continued to Moderate in the UK and Euro Area but Ticked Up in the US, Canada and Japan

We consider AHE for total private industries in the US, compensation per employee in the Euro area, contractual earnings index per FT employee in Japan, AWE (regular pay) for the whole economy in the UK, the quarterly wage price index in Australia, and average hourly wages of permanent employees in Canada. We consider negotiated hourly earnings ex one-off payments in Germany, contractual wages per employee in Italy, agreed wage from collective bargaining in Spain and monthly wage incl. special payments from collective bargaining in the Netherlands. The Euro area Indeed posted wage growth is a new indicator of wage growth based on wages and salaries posted in Indeed job ads, which is a more timely indicator of wage growth for new hires.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 14: Consumer Sentiment Improved Outside the Euro Area

In each country we consider the most prominent survey- based indicator of consumer confidence. These are the UMich Consumer Sentiment and the Conference Board Consumer Confidence in the US, the European Commission Consumer Confidence Indicator in the Euro area, the GfK Consumer Confidence Barometer in the UK, the Cabinet Office's Consumer Confidence Index in Japan, and the Westpac- Melbourne Institute's Consumer Sentiment Index in Australia.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 15: Interest Expenses Declined in Canada and the UK but Edged Up from Depressed Levels in Japan
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 16: House Prices Increased Outside of the US

We consider the S&P CoreLogic Case- Shiller HPI for existing single- family residential homes in the US, the residential property price index by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure Transport and Tourism in Japan, the Hypoport HPI in Germany, the INS HPI for houses and apartments in France, the Istat HPI in Italy, the Halifax national HPI for all houses in the UK, the CoreLogic HPI in Australia, and the CREA MLS benchmark price in Canada.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 17: Outstanding Consumer Credit Growth Moved Sideways in the US and Ticked Down in Canada on a 3m MA Basis
On the right-hand side, we consider consumer credit in the US and household non-mortgage debt in Canada.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 18: Outstanding Mortgage Debt Declined Sharply in the UK but Remained Positive and Edged Down in the Euro Area
On the right-hand side, we consider consumer credit in the Euro area and consumer credit (ex student loans) in the UK.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 19: Consumer Credit Growth Ticked Up in Japan but Moved Sideways in Australia on a 3m MA Basis
On the right-hand side, we consider consumer credit in Japan and non-mortgage household debt in Australia.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 20: In the US, the Labor Market and Household Balance Sheets Remain Healthy, and Debt Service Ratios Low by Historical Standards
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 21: In Canada the Labor Market Remains Sluggish But Net Worth to Income Ratio High by Historical Standards
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 22: In the Euro Area, the Labor Market Remains Tight and the Net Worth to Income Ratio High by Historical Standards
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 23: In the UK, the Labor Market Remains Sluggish
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 24: In Japan, the Labor Market Remains Tight and the Net Worth to Income Ratio High by Historical Standards
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 25: In Australia, the Net Worth to Income Ratio and the Labor Market Remain Healthy by Historical Standards
We compute the weighted average through July. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for July are assumed to be unchanged relative to June when taking the average.
Source: Haver Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
1. For the US, we maintain the framework introduced in our US consumer dashboard. Outside of the US, we identify the closest and most timely measures of consumer health available in each country.

2. Real spending growth: In the US, we consider six-month real personal consumption expenditure growth. In the Euro area, the UK, and Canada, we measure month-on-month growth in real retail sales. In Canada, the most recent value of real retail sales is nowcasted using Statcan's flash estimates. In Australia, we use the monthly nominal spending indicator, deflated by monthly CPI ex. volatile items and adjusted for housing costs. In Japan, we consider the average between the real consumption activity index and the real consumption trend. To address the volatility of monthly moves, we compute the 6-month moving average (6m MA).

3. Unemployment: We consider the gap between the monthly unemployment rate and OECD NAIRU estimates. In the Euro area and the UK (where furlough schemes limited the rise of unemployment during lockdowns), we apply an adjustment for hours worked during the pandemic.

4. Real income growth: We measure month-on-month growth in real aggregate labor earnings combining data, for instance, on hours worked and hourly earnings. Where available, we combine this with survey-based measures of household income, which help capture fluctuations in non-labor income sources. We again compute the 6m MA to address concerns over large swings in month on month data releases. In the Euro area and Australia, we consider quarterly growth in real disposable income and nowcast it when the most recent quarter is not yet released.

5. Consumer confidence: In each country, we consider the most prominent survey-based indicator of consumer confidence. These are the UMich Consumer Sentiment and the Conference Board Consumer Confidence in the US, the European Commission Consumer Confidence Indicator in the Euro area, the GfK Consumer Confidence Barometer in the UK, the Cabinet Office's Consumer Confidence Index in Japan, and the Westpac-Melbourne Institute's Consumer Sentiment Index in Australia. In Canada, we drop this category given a lack of data.

6. Net worth to income ratio: We consider the ratio of household net worth (inclusive of housing) and disposable income. When the observation for the most recent quarter is not yet available, we nowcast it with a linear regression model featuring predictors available at higher frequency (e.g., changes in home prices and equity prices). As of the June 2025 publication we have removed all pension assets from the measure of UK net worth in an effort to harmonize the net-worth-to-income ratio measures across G10 counterparts. We are comfortable with this change given that pension assets are among the most illiquid forms of wealth, and the UK pension assets have seen a substantive and persistent devaluation that stood out as an outlier when compared to other G10 countries.
7. Debt service ratio: We consider the ratio of household interest payments and disposable income. When the observation for the most recent quarter is not yet
available, we nowcast it with a regression model featuring higher frequency predictors.

8. Real net worth growth: We consider the year-on-year growth rate of real household net worth (inclusive of housing). When the observation for the most recent quarter is not yet available, we nowcast it with a regression model. As of the June 2025 publication we have removed all pension assets from the measure of UK net worth in an effort to harmonize the real net worth growth measures across G10 counterparts. We are comfortable with this change given that pension assets are among the most illiquid forms of wealth, and the UK pension assets have seen a substantive and persistent devaluation that stood out as an outlier when compared to other G10 countries.

9. For all components and non-US economies, we plot the percentile rank of each observation in the country's distribution since 2000. In the US, percentiles are computed since 1980, consistent with our US consumer dashboard.

10. For the unemployment gap and debt service ratio, we consider the inverted percentile rank such that high percentiles correspond to positive outcomes (i.e. low unemployment gaps and low debt service ratios).

11. Weighted average of percentiles: We compute the weighted average of percentiles with weights based on frequency, timeliness, and volatility of the indicator. We compute the weighted average through June. Variables that are not observed or nowcasted for June are assumed to be unchanged relative to May when taking the average. The weights are \(20\%\) on real spending growth, \(20\%\) on the unemployment gap, \(20\%\) on consumer confidence, \(15\%\) on real income growth, \(10\%\) on debt service ratio, \(10\%\) on real net worth growth, and \(5\%\) on net worth to income ratio.
